articles.headline: Russian-American Lobbyist Attended Meeting Organized by Trump’s Son
articles.snippet: The lobbyist’s presence adds a twist to the evolving story about the meeting, which Donald Trump Jr. set up after learning a Russian lawyer had damaging information about Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: The lobbyist’s presence adds a twist to the evolving story about the meeting, which Donald Trump Jr. set up after learning a Russian lawyer had damaging information about Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is a veteran of the Red Army, photographed in the 1980s with fellow soldiers in a Russian birch forest. He collects fine art, likes opera and owns a nearly $2 million townhouse in trendy Logan Circle, in the center of Washington. He often zips around the city on a bright orange bicycle.
articles.byline: By Eileen Sullivan, Kenneth P. Vogel, Adam Goldman and Jo Becker

articles.headline: While Some Cry ‘Fake,’ Spotify Sees No Need to Apologize
articles.snippet: Spotify’s playlists are dotted with hundreds of songs done by composers under pseudonyms, but the company says it is just soliciting music to meet demand.
articles.abstract: Spotify’s playlists are dotted with hundreds of songs done by composers under pseudonyms, but the company says it is just soliciting music to meet demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Apple stirred controversy by striking special deals with some of pop music’s biggest stars. Now Spotify is under fire for dealings with artists who, in a sense, do not exist at all.

articles.headline: Back in Afghan Hot Spot, U.S. Marines Chase Diminished Goals
articles.snippet: Marines have returned to Helmand Province to help Afghan forces regain ground lost to the Taliban, and this time there is no timetable for leaving.
articles.abstract: Marines have returned to Helmand Province to help Afghan forces regain ground lost to the Taliban, and this time there is no timetable for leaving.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP SHORAB, Afghanistan — The last time American Marines were in Helmand Province, they had a sweeping mission and the resources to carry it out.

articles.headline: Governors From Both Parties Denounce Senate Obamacare Repeal Bill
articles.snippet: The nation’s governors, gathered for their annual conference, came out against the latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act but for very different reasons.
articles.abstract: The nation’s governors, gathered for their annual conference, came out against the latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act but for very different reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The nation’s governors, gathered here for their annual summer meeting, came out strongly on Friday against the new Senate bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, turning up the pressure on Republican leaders struggling to round up the votes to pass the bill next week.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Noncompete Pacts, Under Siege, Find Haven in Idaho
articles.snippet: As some states make it harder to block workers from going elsewhere, Idaho has passed a law that tips the scale toward their employers.
articles.abstract: As some states make it harder to block workers from going elsewhere, Idaho has passed a law that tips the scale toward their employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — Idaho achieved a notable distinction last year: It became one of the hardest places in America for someone to quit a job for a better one.

articles.headline: The Lawyer, the Addict
articles.snippet: A high-powered Silicon Valley attorney dies. His ex-wife investigates, and finds a web of drug abuse in his profession.
articles.abstract: A high-powered Silicon Valley attorney dies. His ex-wife investigates, and finds a web of drug abuse in his profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July 2015, something was very wrong with my ex-husband, Peter. His behavior over the preceding 18 months had been erratic and odd. He could be angry and threatening one minute, remorseful and generous the next. His voice mail messages and texts had become meandering soliloquies that didn’t make sense, veering from his work travails, to car repairs, to his pet mouse, Snowball.

articles.headline: Iran Dominates in Iraq After U.S. ‘Handed the Country Over’
articles.snippet: The United States spent more than $1 trillion and lost about 4,500 troops in the effort to make Iraq the cornerstone of a Western-facing Middle East. But today, Iran’s influence is paramount.
articles.abstract: The United States spent more than $1 trillion and lost about 4,500 troops in the effort to make Iraq the cornerstone of a Western-facing Middle East. But today, Iran’s influence is paramount.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Walk into almost any market in Iraq and the shelves are filled with goods from Iran — milk, yogurt, chicken. Turn on the television and channel after channel broadcasts programs sympathetic to Iran.

articles.headline: At a Luxury Complex in India, the Maids and the Madams Go to War
articles.snippet: A dispute between a maid and her employer led to a full-blown riot, an unusual boiling over of resentment between rich and poor in India.
articles.abstract: A dispute between a maid and her employer led to a full-blown riot, an unusual boiling over of resentment between rich and poor in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOIDA, India — The madams in the luxury gated community went to yoga classes and toddler playgroups; the maids soundlessly whisked away dirty dishes and soiled laundry before retreating, at night, to a nearby shantytown of tin sheds and plastic tents.
articles.byline: By Suhasini Raj and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Going Around Trump, Governors Embark on Their Own Diplomatic Missions
articles.snippet: Leadership at the state level has taken on an increasingly global dimension amid worries that Mr. Trump is abandoning the typical priorities of the government.
articles.abstract: Leadership at the state level has taken on an increasingly global dimension amid worries that Mr. Trump is abandoning the typical priorities of the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington, a Democrat, huddled with the leaders of Mexico and Canada in the space of 48 hours this spring, racing to Mexico City from Seattle for back-to-back discussions on climate change and trade.

articles.headline: Soviet Veteran Who Met With Trump Jr. Is a Master of the Dark Arts
articles.snippet: Rinat Akhmetshin, a gregarious, fast-talking man with a sharp sense of humor, has often warned his friends and contacts: “Nothing is secure.”
articles.abstract: Rinat Akhmetshin, a gregarious, fast-talking man with a sharp sense of humor, has often warned his friends and contacts: “Nothing is secure.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Rinat Akhmetshin, the Russian-American lobbyist who met with Donald Trump Jr. at Trump Tower in June 2016, had one consistent message for the journalists who met him over the years at the luxury hotels where he stayed in Moscow, London and Paris, or at his home on a leafy street in Washington: Never use email to convey information that needed to be kept secret.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: McCain’s Surgery Will Delay Senate Votes on Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: With John McCain’s absence, Republicans would have only 49 votes to move ahead with the legislation; all Democrats and the two independent senators oppose it.
articles.abstract: With John McCain’s absence, Republicans would have only 49 votes to move ahead with the legislation; all Democrats and the two independent senators oppose it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate will delay votes on a bill to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, announced Saturday night, because of a new obstacle to winning enough support for one of the Republican Party’s most cherished goals.

articles.headline: She’s His Rock. His Parole Officer Won’t Let Him See Her.
articles.snippet: As prison rolls drop and the number of parolees increases, a Connecticut man learns that getting out of prison is not the same as being free.
articles.abstract: As prison rolls drop and the number of parolees increases, a Connecticut man learns that getting out of prison is not the same as being free.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, Conn. — During Erroll Brantley Jr.’s nearly two years in prison, his girlfriend, Katherine Eaton, visited him three times a week, the maximum allowed. She wrote him letters and spent hundreds of dollars on phone calls, during which the couple spoke of their longing to be back together in her three-bedroom house with the picture window. Amid the I love yous and I miss yous, she promised to help him stay off heroin and readjust to life outside.

articles.headline: Welcome to Manhood, Gillette Told the 50-Year-Old Woman
articles.snippet: A marketing effort to get free razors in the hands of young men for their 18th birthdays has sometimes reached the wrong target.
articles.abstract: A marketing effort to get free razors in the hands of young men for their 18th birthdays has sometimes reached the wrong target.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 50-year-old professor and mother in Tuscaloosa, Ala. A 19-year-old woman in Toledo, Iowa. A 48-year-old man who lives in Seattle.

articles.headline: A Russian Developer Helps Out the Kremlin on Occasion. Was He a Conduit to Trump?
articles.snippet: Aras Agalarov had developed a reputation as a fixer for the Kremlin’s toughest jobs. Did that include trying to pass dirt to Trump’s son and aides?
articles.abstract: Aras Agalarov had developed a reputation as a fixer for the Kremlin’s toughest jobs. Did that include trying to pass dirt to Trump’s son and aides?
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian Island, near the port city of Vladivostok in the far east, was a decaying former military base and home to a scattering of cattle when President Vladimir V. Putin suddenly envisioned it as a $1.2 billion campus where he could welcome heads of state for an Asia-Pacific conference.

articles.headline: Qatar Opens Its Doors to All, to the Dismay of Some
articles.snippet: The tiny country has become the freewheeling hub of the Middle East. But assertions that it is furthering dissent and terrorism have led to a blockade.
articles.abstract: The tiny country has become the freewheeling hub of the Middle East. But assertions that it is furthering dissent and terrorism have led to a blockade.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Take a drive in Doha, leaving behind the mirrored skyscrapers and palm-fringed avenues of this gas-rich city, and the protagonists of myriad conflicts are in easy reach.

articles.headline: Behind the Velvet Ropes of Facebook’s Private Groups
articles.snippet: To understand Facebook’s new emphasis on private groups, I joined more than 100, ranging from gardeners to flat-earth truthers.
articles.abstract: To understand Facebook’s new emphasis on private groups, I joined more than 100, ranging from gardeners to flat-earth truthers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent days, I’ve gotten to know beekeepers in Rhode Island, dental hygienists in New Jersey and Wiccans in Tennessee. I’ve seen gardeners swapping fertilizer advice, flight attendants complaining about annoying passengers and fishermen arguing about which lures are best for catching muskies. I now know that there are hundreds of people who love creating memes about “The Sopranos,” and thousands who believe, with total conviction, that the Earth is flat.

articles.headline: Wealth Advisers Set Up Shop With a Shared Back Office
articles.snippet: Online technology lets independent advisers pose a direct threat to the old model of huddling with brokers in paneled offices in big brokerage houses.
articles.abstract: Online technology lets independent advisers pose a direct threat to the old model of huddling with brokers in paneled offices in big brokerage houses.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to traditional financial advisers, Josh Brown of Ritholtz Wealth Management does not quite play to type.

articles.headline: In Urban China, Cash Is Rapidly Becoming Obsolete
articles.snippet: Across the country's cities, the rapid growth of mobile payments is making cash all but obsolete.
articles.abstract: Across the country's cities, the rapid growth of mobile payments is making cash all but obsolete.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — There is an audacious economic phenomenon happening in China.

articles.headline: A Top Republican Vows a Vote on Health Care, but Uncertainty Reigns
articles.snippet: It was not clear how long a delay caused by the absence of Senator John McCain would last, and detractors said they would use it to mobilize more opposition.
articles.abstract: It was not clear how long a delay caused by the absence of Senator John McCain would last, and detractors said they would use it to mobilize more opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top Senate Republican vowed on Sunday to bring the party’s health care bill to a vote as soon as possible, even as detractors said they would use a delay caused by the absence of Senator John McCain to mobilize further opposition to the measure.

articles.headline: Cosmo DiNardo Took a Dark Turn Before Bucks County Killings, Friends Say
articles.snippet: Before Mr. DiNardo confessed to killing four young men in Pennsylvania, there were signs of a volatile, bullying personality getting worse over time.
articles.abstract: Before Mr. DiNardo confessed to killing four young men in Pennsylvania, there were signs of a volatile, bullying personality getting worse over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENSALEM, Pa. — Women blocked him on social media, saying he aggressively stalked them for dates and sex.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Matthew Haag and Jon Hurdle

articles.headline: South Korea Proposes Military Talks With North at Their Border
articles.snippet: Such talks would be the first in years, and the North’s reaction will be the first test of the new South Korean president’s pro-dialogue policy.
articles.abstract: Such talks would be the first in years, and the North’s reaction will be the first test of the new South Korean president’s pro-dialogue policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Monday proposed holding military and humanitarian talks with North Korea, its first visible split with the Trump administration, which has said it will deal with North Korea’s continued missile tests by stepping up sanctions and military pressure on the country.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Cost of a Hot Economy in California: A Severe Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: An explosion in costs has emerged as a central problem for the state, and state and local governments are pondering a series of measures to correct course.
articles.abstract: An explosion in costs has emerged as a central problem for the state, and state and local governments are pondering a series of measures to correct course.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — A full-fledged housing crisis has gripped California, marked by a severe lack of affordable homes and apartments for middle-class families. The median cost of a home here is now a staggering $500,000, twice the national cost. Homelessness is surging across the state.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Struggles at Procter & Gamble Draw Scrutiny of Nelson Peltz
articles.snippet: Mr. Peltz’s Trian Fund Management is seeking a board seat at the consumer products giant, signaling a ratcheting-up in the size of the corporate targets of activist investors.
articles.abstract: Mr. Peltz’s Trian Fund Management is seeking a board seat at the consumer products giant, signaling a ratcheting-up in the size of the corporate targets of activist investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tide detergent dominated the American laundry room for decades and helped make Procter & Gamble a consumer products behemoth.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: K.K.R. Lays Out a Line of Succession, a Rare Move in Private Equity
articles.snippet: Joseph Bae and Scott Nuttall will become co-presidents and co-chief operating officers of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, setting them up as heirs to the firm’s co-founders.
articles.abstract: Joseph Bae and Scott Nuttall will become co-presidents and co-chief operating officers of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, setting them up as heirs to the firm’s co-founders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few can claim as crucial a role in creating the buyout industry as Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts. From a small partnership that began with just $120,000, the two created the colossus now known as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the firm that bought RJR Nabisco and defined an era.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
